topic.title: Oracle Compatibility Functions
topic.shortdesc: Describes the Oracle Compatibility SQL functions in Greenplum Database. These functions target PostgreSQL.

body.note:
The Oracle Compatibility Functions reside in the oracompat schema. To access them, prefix the schema name (oracompat) or alter the database search path to include the schema name. For example:ALTER DATABASE db_name SET search_path = $user, public, oracompat;

topic.domains: (topic ui-d) (topic hi-d) (topic pr-d) (topic sw-d) (topic ut-d) (topic indexing-d)
topic.title: Oracle and Greenplum Implementation Differences

body.p: There are some differences in the implementation of these compatibility functions in the Greenplum Database from the Oracle implementation. If you use validation scripts, the output may not be exactly the same as in Oracle. Some of the differences are as follows:

ul.li:
Oracle performs a decimal round off, Greenplum Database does not:
2.00 becomes 2 in Oracle.
2.0.0 remains 2.00 in Greenplum Database.

Numbers in bigint format are displayed in scientific notation in Oracle, but not in Greenplum Database:
9223372036854775 displays as 9.2234E+15 in Oracle.
9223372036854775 remains 9223372036854775 in Greenplum Database.

The default date and timestamp format in Oracle is different than the default format in Greenplum Database. If the following code is executed:CREATE TABLE TEST(date1 date, time1 timestamp, time2 timestamp with timezone); INSERT INTO TEST VALUES ('2001-11-11','2001-12-13 01:51:15','2001-12-13 01:51:15 -08:00'); SELECT DECODE(date1, '2001-11-11', '2001-01-01') FROM TEST;
Greenplum Database returns the row, but Oracle does not return any rows.The correct syntax in Oracle to return the row is:SELECT DECODE(to_char(date1, 'YYYY-MM-DD'), '2001-11-11', '2001-01-01') FROM TEST

topic.title: add_months

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to add a given number of months to a given date.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function adds months_to_add to a date_expression and returns a DATE.

If the date_expression specifies the last day of the month, or if the resulting month has fewer days than the date_expression, then the returned value is the last day of the resulting month. Otherwise, the returned value has the same day of the month as the date_expression.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The starting date. This can be any expression that can be implicitly converted to DATE.
The number of months to add to the date_expression. This is an integer or any value that can be implicitly converted to an integer. This parameter can be positive or negative.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: SELECT name, phone, nextcalldate FROM clientdb WHERE nextcalldate >= add_months(CURRENT_DATE,6);
section.p: Returns name, phone, and nextcalldate for all records where nextcalldate is at least six months in the future.
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: bitand

body.p: Oracle-compliant function that computes a logical AND operation on the bits of two non-negative values.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function returns an integer representing an AND operation on the bits of two non-negative values (expr1 and expr2). 1 is returned when the values are the same. 0 is returned when the values are different. Only significant bits are compared. For example, an AND operation on the integers 5 (binary 101) and 1 (binary 001 or 1) compares only the rightmost bit, and results in a value of 1 (binary 1).
The types of expr1 and expr2 are NUMBER, and the result is of type NUMBER. If either argument is NULL, the result is NULL.
The arguments must be in the range -(2(n-1)) .. ((2(n-1))-1). If an argument is out of this range, the result is undefined.

ul.li: The current implementation of BITAND defines n = 128.
PL/SQL supports an overload of BITAND for which the types of the inputs and of the result are all BINARY_INTEGER and for which n = 32.

section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: A non-negative integer expression.
A non-negative integer expression.

section.title: Example
Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: concat

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to concatenate two strings together.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function concatenates two strings (string1 and string2) together.
The string returned is in the same character set as string1. Its datatype depends on the datatypes of the arguments.

In concatenations of two different datatypes, the datatype returned is the one that results in a lossless conversion. Therefore, if one of the arguments is a LOB, then the returned value is a LOB. If one of the arguments is a national datatype, then the returned value is a national datatype. For example:
section.codeblock: concat(CLOB, NCLOB) returns NCLOB concat(NCLOB, NCHAR) returns NCLOB concat(NCLOB, CHAR) returns NCLOB concat(NCHAR, CLOB) returns NCLOB
section.p: This function is equivalent to the concatenation operator (||).
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The two strings to concatenate together.
Both string1 and string2 can be any of the datatypes CHAR, VARCHAR2, NCHAR, NVARCHAR2, CLOB, or NCLOB.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: SELECT concat(concat(last_name, '''s job category is '), job_id) FROM employees
section.p: Returns 'Smith's job category is 4B'
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: decode

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to transform a data value to a specified return value. This function is a way to implement a set of CASE statements.
body.note: decode is converted into a reserved word in Greenplum Database. If you want to use the Postgres two-argument decode function that decodes binary strings previously encoded to ASCII-only representation, you must invoke it by using the full schema-qualified syntax, pg_catalog.decode(), or by enclosing the function name in quotes "decode" ().

Greenplum's implementation of this function transforms decode into case.
This results in the following type of output:gptest=# select decode(a, 1, 'A', 2, 'B', 'C') from decodetest; case ------ C A C B C (5 rows)
This also means that if you deparse your view with decode, you will see case expression instead.
body.p: You should use the case function instead of decode.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: The Oracle-compatible function decode searches for a value in an expression. If the value is found, the function returns the specified value.
section.note: This function is available by default and can be accessed without running the Oracle Compatibility installer.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The expression to search.
The value to find in the expression.
What to return if expression matches value.
What to return if expression does not match any of the values.

section.p: Only one expression is passed to the function. Multiple value/return pairs can be passed.

The default parameter is optional. If default is not specified and if expression does not match any of the passed value parameters, decode returns null. The Greenplum implementation restricts return and default to be of the same data type. The expression and value can be different types if the data type of value can be converted into the data type of the expression. This is done implicitly. Otherwise, decode fails with an invalid input syntax error.
section.title: Examples
section.p: In the following code, decode searches for a value for company_id and returns a specified value for that company. If company_id not one of the listed values, the default value Other is returned.
The following code using CASE statements to produce the same result as the example using decode.
section.codeblock: SELECT CASE company_id WHEN IS NOT DISTINCT FROM 1 THEN 'EMC' WHEN IS NOT DISTINCT FROM 2 THEN 'Greenplum' ELSE 'Other' END FROM suppliers;
section.title: Notes
section.p: To assign a range of values to a single return value, either pass an expression for each value in the range, or pass an expression that evaluates identically for all values in the range. For example, if a fiscal year begins on August 1, the quarters are shown in the following table.

table.title: Months and Quarters for Fiscal Year Beginning on August 1

section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.
section.title: See Also
section.p: PostgreSQL decode (not compatible with Oracle)

topic.title: instr

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to return the location of a substring in a string.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function searches for a substring in a string. If found, it returns an integer indicating the position of the substring in the string, if not found, the function returns 0.
Optionally you can specify that the search starts at a given position in the string, and only return the nth occurrence of the substring in the string.
instr calculates strings using characters as defined by the input character set.
The value returned is of NUMBER datatype.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The string to search.
The substring to search for in string.
Both string and substring can be any of the datatypes CHAR, VARCHAR2, NCHAR, NVARCHAR2, CLOB, or NCLOB.

The position is a nonzero integer in string where the search will start. If not specified, this defaults to 1. If this value is negative, the function counts backwards from the end of string then searches towards to beginning from the resulting position.
Occurrence is an integer indicating which occurrence of the substring should be searched for. The value of occurrence must be positive.

Both position and occurrence must be of datatype NUMBER, or any datatype that can be implicitly converted to NUMBER, and must resolve to an integer. The default values of both position and occurrence are 1, meaning that the search begins at the first character of string for the first occurrence of substring. The return value is relative to the beginning of string, regardless of the value of position, and is expressed in characters.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Returns 3; the first occurrence of 'e'
Returns 4; the second occurrence of 'e'
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: months_between

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to evaluate the number of months between two given dates.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function returns the number of months between date_expression1 and date_expression2.
If date_expression1 is later than date_expression2, then the result is positive.
If date_expression1 is earlier than date_expression2, then the result is negative.

If date_expression1 and date_expression2 are either the same days of the month or both last days of months, then the result is always an integer. Otherwise the function calculates the fractional portion of the month based on a 31-day month.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The date values used to calculate the number of months. This can be any expression that can be implicitly converted to DATE.

section.title: Examples
section.p: Returns the number of months between July 1, 2003 and March 14, 2014.
section.codeblock: SELECT * FROM employees where months_between(hire_date, leave_date) <12;
section.p: Returns the number of months between hire_date and leave_date.
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: nanvl

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to substitute a value for a floating point number when a non-number value is encountered.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function evaluates a floating point number (float1) such as BINARY_FLOAT or BINARY_DOUBLE. If it is a non-number ('not a number', NaN), the function returns float2. This function is most commonly used to convert non-number values into either NULL or 0.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The BINARY_FLOAT or BINARY_NUMBER to evaluate.
The value to return if float1 is not a number.

float1 and float2 can be any numeric datatype or any nonnumeric datatype that can be implicitly converted to a numeric datatype. The function determines the argument with the highest numeric precedence, implicitly converts the remaining arguments to that datatype, and returns that datatype.

section.title: Example
section.p: Returns 0 if the binary1 field contained a non-number value. Otherwise, it would return the binary1 value.
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: next_day

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to return the date of the next specified weekday after a date.
This section describes using this function with a string argument; see the following page for details about using this function with an integer argument.
body.note: This function is an overloaded function. There are two Oracle-compliant next_day functions, one that takes a date and a day of the week as its arguments (see below), and one that takes a date and an integer as its arguments (see next page).

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function returns the first day_of_the_week (Tuesday, Wednesday, etc.) to occur after a date_expression.
The weekday must be specified in English.
The case of the weekday is irrelevant.
The return type is always DATE, regardless of the datatype of date_expression.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The starting date. This can be any expression that can be implicitly converted to DATE.
A string containing the name of a day, in English; for example 'Tuesday'. day_of_the_week is case-insensitive.

section.title: Example
section.codeblock: SELECT name, next_day(hiredate,"MONDAY") "Second Week Start" FROM employees;
section.p: Returns the name and the date of the next Monday after hiredate labeled "Second Week Start".
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.

topic.title: round

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to round a date to a specific unit of measure (day, week, etc.).
body.note: This function is an overloaded function. It shares the same name with the Postgres round mathematical function that rounds numeric input to the nearest integer or optionally to the nearest x number of decimal places.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function rounds a date_time_expression to the nearest unit_of_measure (day, week, etc.). If a unit_of_measure is not specified, the date_time_expression is rounded to the nearest day. It operates according to the rules of the Gregorian calendar.
If the date_time_expression datatype is TIMESTAMP, the value returned is always of datatype TIMESTAMP.
If the date_time_expression datatype is DATE, the value returned is always of datatype DATE.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The date to round. This can be any expression that can be implicitly converted to DATE or TIMESTAMP.
The unit of measure to apply for rounding. If not specified, then the date_time_expression is rounded to the nearest day. Valid parameters are:

row.entry: SYYYY, YYYY, YEAR, SYEAR, YYY, YY, Y
Rounds up on the 16th day of the second month of the quarter
Rounds up on the 16th day of the month
Same day of the week as the first day of the year
Same day of the week as the first day of the ISO year
Same day of the week as the first day of the month
Rounds to the nearest start (sunday) day of the week

section.title: Example
section.p: Returns '01-JAN-01' (27 Oct 00 rounded to the first day of the following year (YEAR))
Returns '01-JUL-92' (the startdate rounded to the first day of the quarter (Q))
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.
section.title: See Also
section.p: PostgreSQL round (not compatible with Oracle)

topic.title: tanh

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to return the hyperbolic tangent of a given number.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function returns the hyperbolic tangent of the floating 8 input number (float8).

note.p: This function is available by default and can be accessed without running the Oracle Compatibility installer.

section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The input number.

section.title: Example
section.p: Returns '0.99505475368673'' (hyperbolic tangent of 3)

topic.title: trunc

body.p: Oracle-compliant function to truncate a date to a specific unit of measure (day, week, hour, etc.).

note.p: This function is an overloaded function. It shares the same name with the Postgres trunc and the Oracle trunc mathematical functions. Both of these truncate numeric input to the nearest integer or optionally to the nearest x number of decimal places.

section.title: Synopsis
Description
section.p: This Oracle-compatible function truncates a date_time_expression to the nearest unit_of_measure (day, week, etc.). If a unit_of_measure is not specified, the date_time_expression is truncated to the nearest day. It operates according to the rules of the Gregorian calendar.
If the date_time_expression datatype is TIMESTAMP, the value returned is always of datatype TIMESTAMP, truncated to the hour/min level.
If the date_time_expression datatype is DATE, the value returned is always of datatype DATE.
section.title: Parameters

plentry.pd: The date to truncate. This can be any expression that can be implicitly converted to DATE or TIMESTAMP.
The unit of measure to apply for truncating. If not specified, then date__time_expression is truncated to the nearest day. Valid formats are:

row.entry: SYYYY, YYYY, YEAR, SYEAR, YYY, YY, Y

section.title: Examples
section.p: Returns '01-JAN-92' (27 Oct 92 truncated to the first day of the year (YEAR))
Returns '1992-07-01' (the startdate truncated to the first day of the quarter (Q), depending on the date_style setting)
section.title: Compatibility
section.p: This command is compatible with Oracle syntax and is provided for convenience.
